sandypython.core¶

sandypython.core.restrict(module, name)[source]¶

Add name of module to the list of module members to remove on starting the sandbox

Example:

restrict("builtins", "any")
sandypython.core.allow(module, name)[source]¶

Remove name of module to the list of module members to remove on starting the sandbox

Example:

allow("allow", "type")
sandypython.core.replace(module, name, obj)[source]¶

Add name of module to the list of module members to replace on starting the sandbox

Example:

replace("builtins", "print", my_printer)
sandypython.core.allow_builtin(name)[source]¶

Equivalent to allow(), with module being builtins

Example:

allow_builtin("type")
sandypython.core.allow_defaults()[source]¶

Allow a default list of builtins that are considered to be safe

sandypython.core.replace_builtin(name, obj)[source]¶

Equivalent to replace(), with module being builtins

Example:

replace_builtin("__import__", utils.checked_imported(imp_map))
sandypython.core.add_to_exec_globals(name, obj)[source]¶

Adds an object which can be accessed by the sandboxed code as a global.

sandypython.core.start_sandbox()[source]¶

If the sandbox has not been started, start it. This function removes all special attributes, restricted module members, and does module member replacements.

Also see sandypython.utils.ActivateSandbox

sandypython.core.end_sandbox()[source]¶

If the sandbox has been started, revert the interpreter state back to that before start_sandbox() was called.

Also see sandypython.utils.DeactivateSandbox

sandypython.core.exec_str(code_str)[source]¶

Executes code_str under the sandbox. start_sandbox() is called before executing the string.

sandypython.core.detamper_builtins(force=False)[source]¶

Checks the members of the builtins module to make sure that they are the same as before the code was executed.

Also see sandypython.utils.check_builtins

sandypython.core.on_start(f)[source]¶

Add a function to be called before the sandbox starts.

sandypython.core.on_end(f)[source]¶

Add a function to be called once the sandbox ends.

sandypython.core.reset()[source]¶

Resets the state of the sandbox, so that new code can be run without the effects of the old code.

sandypython
